content.question: Cui mater media sese tulit obvia silva, virginis os habitumque gerens et virginis arma Spartanae, vel qualis equos Threissa fatigat Harpalyce volucremque fuga praevertitur Hebrum. 5Namque umeris de more habilem suspenderat arcum venatrix dederatque comam diffundere ventis, nuda genu nodoque sinus collecta fluentes. Aeneid 1. 314-320 Answer the following questions in English unless the question specifically asks you to write out Latin words. Number your answer to each question. 1. (A) Identify one and only one literary device found in line 1 (Cui . . . silva) and (B) write out the Latin word or words that illustrate it. 2. In lines 1-3 (Cui . . . Spartanae), (A) identify one Latin word that modifies mater (line 1) and (B) translate it in context. 3. In lines 1-4 (Cui . . . Hebrum), identify three Latin words that are direct objects of gerens (line 2). 4. In this passage, which two Latin words can be translated “she surpasses in her escape”? 5. In this passage, (A) identify the two pluperfect verbs and (B) translate them in context with their direct objects. 6. In lines 5-7 (Namque . . . fluentes), which four Latin words indicate that the woman has arranged her clothes to be ready for hunting? 7. Later in Book 1, what further action does Venus take to ensure Aeneas’s safety in Carthage?

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 1.B: Describe how grammar contributes to the meaning and function of Latin words and phrases in context.
